title: Installation of Ubuntu on Virtual Machine using Oracle VirtualBox

questions.question: Aim
questions.answer: To install the Ubuntu operating system on a virtual machine using Oracle VM VirtualBox.

questions.question: Concept of Virtual Machine
questions.answer: A Virtual Machine (VM) is a software-based emulation of a physical computer. It allows multiple operating systems to run on a single physical system. Each virtual machine works independently and is allocated its own resources such as CPU, RAM, storage, and network interfaces.

questions.question: Software Requirements
questions.answer:
• Oracle VM VirtualBox
  • Ubuntu ISO image
  • Host Operating System (Windows/Linux)

questions.question: Procedure to Install Oracle VirtualBox
questions.answer:
1. Open a web browser and visit https://www.virtualbox.org.
  2. Download Oracle VM VirtualBox for Windows Hosts.
  3. Run the downloaded setup file.
  4. Click Next and keep default installation settings.
  5. Click Install and allow necessary permissions.
  6. Wait until the installation completes successfully.

questions.question: Procedure to Install Ubuntu on VirtualBox
questions.answer:
1. Download Ubuntu ISO file from https://ubuntu.com/download.
  2. Open Oracle VirtualBox and click New.
  3. Enter Name as Ubuntu, Type as Linux, and Version as Ubuntu (64-bit).
  4. Allocate memory size (minimum 2048 MB).
  5. Create a virtual hard disk (VDI → Dynamically Allocated).
  6. Set virtual disk size (minimum 20 GB).
  7. Go to Settings → Storage and attach the Ubuntu ISO file.
  8. Start the virtual machine.
  9. Select Install Ubuntu and follow on-screen instructions.
  10. Set keyboard layout, timezone, username, and password.
  11. Complete the installation and reboot the virtual machine.

questions.question: Observation
questions.answer: Ubuntu installation process completed successfully and the system booted into the Ubuntu desktop environment.

questions.question: Result
questions.answer: Ubuntu operating system was successfully installed on a virtual machine using Oracle VirtualBox.

title: Getting System Information using Command Line

questions.question: Aim
questions.answer: To obtain system information of a virtual machine such as guest operating system name, allocated RAM, virtual disk size, VirtualBox version, and CPU details using command line.

questions.question: System Requirements
questions.answer:
• Ubuntu operating system installed on VirtualBox
  • Terminal access
  • Oracle VM VirtualBox

questions.question: Command to Get Guest Operating System Information
questions.answer:
The following command is used to display the guest operating system details:

lsb_release -a

questions.question: Command to Check Allocated RAM
questions.answer:
The following command displays total, used, and free memory:

free -h

questions.question: Command to Get CPU Information
questions.answer:
The following command shows CPU architecture, number of cores, and processor details:

lscpu

questions.question: Command to Get Virtual Disk Size
questions.answer:
The following command displays information about block devices and virtual disks:

lsblk

questions.question: Command to Get Kernel Version
questions.answer:
The following command displays the Linux kernel version:

uname -r

questions.question: Command to Get VirtualBox Version
questions.answer:
The following command is used on the host machine to check the VirtualBox version:

VBoxManage --version

questions.question: Observation
questions.answer: All system details such as operating system version, memory size, CPU cores, disk size, and VirtualBox version were displayed correctly using command line utilities.

questions.question: Result
questions.answer: The system information of the virtual machine was successfully obtained using various Linux command line commands.

title: Installation of GCC Compiler in Ubuntu

questions.question: Aim
questions.answer: To install the GNU Compiler Collection (GCC) in Ubuntu Linux and compile a simple C program.

questions.question: Software Requirements
questions.answer:
• Ubuntu operating system
  • Terminal access
  • Internet connection

questions.question: About GCC
questions.answer: GCC (GNU Compiler Collection) is a free and open-source compiler system developed by the GNU Project. It is used to compile programming languages such as C, C++, and others.

questions.question: Procedure to Install GCC
questions.answer:
The following commands are used to install GCC in Ubuntu:

sudo apt update
sudo apt install gcc

questions.question: Command to Verify GCC Installation
questions.answer:
The following command is used to verify whether GCC is installed successfully:

gcc --version

questions.question: Sample C Program
questions.answer:
#include <stdio.h>
int main() {
    printf("Hello World");
    return 0;
}

questions.question: Compile and Execute the Program
questions.answer:
The following commands are used to compile and execute the C program:

gcc program.c
./a.out

questions.question: Output
questions.answer: Hello World

questions.question: Observation
questions.answer: The C program compiled successfully without errors and produced the expected output.

questions.question: Result
questions.answer: The GCC compiler was successfully installed in Ubuntu and a C program was compiled and executed successfully.

questions.question: Aim
questions.answer: To write and execute basic shell scripts in Linux for displaying date and time, accepting user input, and implementing conditional statements.

questions.question: Software Requirements
questions.answer:
• Ubuntu operating system
  • Terminal access
  • Bash shell

questions.question: Script to Display Current Date and Time
questions.answer:
The following shell script is used to display the current date and time:

#!/bin/bash
echo "Current Date and Time: $(date)"

questions.question: Script to Display Only Current Time
questions.answer:
The following script displays only the current system time:

#!/bin/bash
echo "Current Time: $(date +%H:%M:%S)"

questions.question: Script to Accept User Input
questions.answer:
The following shell script accepts a user name as input and displays a welcome message:

#!/bin/bash
echo "Enter your name:"
read name
echo "Hello $name! Welcome to Linux Shell Scripting."

questions.question: Shell Script using IF-ELSE Statement
questions.answer:
The following script demonstrates the use of if-else condition:

#!/bin/bash
x=10
y=20
if [ $x -lt $y ]
then
  echo "$x is less than $y"
else
  echo "$x is greater than $y"
fi

questions.question: Shell Script using IF-ELIF-ELSE Statement
questions.answer:
The following script demonstrates the use of if-elif-else condition:

#!/bin/bash
x=20
y=50
if [ $x -lt $y ]
then
  echo "$x is less than $y"
elif [ $x -eq $y ]
then
  echo "$x is equal to $y"
else
  echo "$x is greater than $y"
fi

questions.question: Execution of Shell Script
questions.answer:
To execute the shell script, use the following commands:

chmod +x script.sh
./script.sh

questions.question: Observation
questions.answer: All shell scripts executed successfully and produced the expected output.

questions.question: Result
questions.answer: Basic shell scripting operations were successfully implemented using Bash shell.

questions.question: Aim
questions.answer: To understand and change file permissions in Linux using command line.

questions.question: Software Requirements
questions.answer:
• Ubuntu operating system
  • Terminal access
  • Basic knowledge of Linux commands

questions.question: Concept of File Permissions
questions.answer: In Linux, file permissions determine who can read, write, or execute a file. There are three types of users: owner, group, and others. Each file has three permission types: read (r), write (w), and execute (x).

questions.question: Command to View File Permissions
questions.answer:
The following command is used to view file permissions:

ls -l

questions.question: Command to Change File Permission
questions.answer:
The chmod command is used to change file permissions:

chmod +x filename.sh

questions.question: Numeric Method of chmod
questions.answer:
File permissions can also be changed using numeric values:

chmod 755 filename.sh

Here, 7 represents read, write, and execute permissions for owner, and 5 represents read and execute permissions for group and others.

questions.question: Execution of File After Permission Change
questions.answer:
After changing permission, the file can be executed using:

./filename.sh

questions.question: Observation
questions.answer: The file permissions were successfully changed and the file executed without any permission error.

questions.question: Result
questions.answer: File permissions were successfully modified using the chmod command in Linux.

title: Pinging One Virtual Machine to Another Using NAT

questions.question: Aim
questions.answer: To test network connectivity between two virtual machines using the ping command and NAT networking in VirtualBox.

questions.question: Software Requirements
questions.answer:
• Oracle VM VirtualBox
  • Two Ubuntu virtual machines
  • Terminal access

questions.question: Concept of NAT
questions.answer: NAT (Network Address Translation) allows virtual machines to access external networks using the host system’s IP address. It also enables communication between virtual machines when configured properly.

questions.question: Steps to Configure NAT Network
questions.answer:
1. Open VirtualBox.
  2. Select the virtual machine → Settings → Network.
  3. Set Adapter 1 as NAT.
  4. Repeat the same steps for the second virtual machine.

questions.question: Command to Get IP Address of VM
questions.answer:
The following command is used to obtain the IP address of the virtual machine:

ip -4 addr show

questions.question: Command to Ping Another Virtual Machine
questions.answer:
Use the following command to check connectivity between two VMs:

ping -c 4 <destination_IP_address>

Example:

ping -c 4 10.0.2.6

questions.question: Saving Ping Output to a File
questions.answer:
The ping output can be saved into a file using:

ping www.google.com >> ping_report.txt

questions.question: Observation
questions.answer: The ping command successfully sent and received packets between the two virtual machines, indicating proper network connectivity.

questions.question: Result
questions.answer: Network connectivity between the two virtual machines was successfully verified using NAT configuration and the ping command.

title: Getting IP Details and File Sharing from One VM to Another Using NAT and SCP

questions.question: Aim
questions.answer: To obtain IP address details of a virtual machine and transfer files between two virtual machines using NAT networking and SCP command.

questions.question: Software Requirements
questions.answer:
• Oracle VM VirtualBox
  • Two Ubuntu virtual machines
  • Terminal access
  • SSH and SCP utilities

questions.question: Command to Get IP Address of Virtual Machine
questions.answer:
The following command is used to display the IP address of the virtual machine:

ip -4 addr show

questions.question: Concept of SCP
questions.answer: SCP (Secure Copy Protocol) is a network protocol used to securely transfer files between hosts over an SSH connection. It ensures secure data transfer using encryption.

questions.question: Installation of SSH Server
questions.answer:
SSH server must be installed on both virtual machines using the following commands:

sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install openssh-server

questions.question: Port Forwarding Configuration for NAT
questions.answer:
When using NAT, port forwarding is required to enable communication between virtual machines.

Port forwarding rules:

VM1:
Host Port: 2222 → Guest Port: 22

VM2:
Host Port: 2223 → Guest Port: 22

questions.question: Command to Transfer File from One VM to Another
questions.answer:
The following SCP command is used to transfer a file:

scp -P 2223 /path/to/file user@localhost:/home/user/

questions.question: Verification of File Transfer
questions.answer:
To verify whether the file is transferred successfully:

ssh user@localhost -p 2223
ls /home/user/

questions.question: Observation
questions.answer: The IP address of the virtual machine was obtained successfully and files were transferred securely between the two virtual machines.

questions.question: Result
questions.answer: IP details were successfully retrieved and file sharing between virtual machines was achieved using NAT and SCP.

questions.question: Aim
questions.answer: To install and configure Google App Engine (GAE) and set up a basic cloud application environment.

questions.question: Software Requirements
questions.answer:
• Ubuntu operating system
  • Google Cloud account
  • Internet connection
  • Python installed

questions.question: About Google App Engine
questions.answer: Google App Engine (GAE) is a cloud computing platform provided by Google that allows users to build and deploy applications on Google-managed infrastructure. It supports multiple programming languages and automatically handles scaling, security, and server management.

questions.question: Downloading Google Cloud SDK
questions.answer:
The Google Cloud SDK is required to work with Google App Engine. It can be downloaded based on the operating system.

Linux 64-bit: google-cloud-cli-linux-x86_64.tar.gz
Linux 32-bit: google-cloud-cli-linux-x86.tar.gz

questions.question: Installation of Google Cloud SDK
questions.answer:
After downloading the SDK, extract and install it using the following commands:

tar -xvf google-cloud-cli-linux-x86_64.tar.gz
cd google-cloud-sdk
./install.sh

questions.question: Initialization of Google Cloud SDK
questions.answer:
The SDK must be initialized to authenticate the user and configure the project:

gcloud init

During initialization, log in with your Google account and select or create a project.

questions.question: Creating Google App Engine Application
questions.answer:
The following command is used to create an App Engine application:

gcloud app create

Select the required region when prompted.

questions.question: Observation
questions.answer: Google Cloud SDK was successfully installed and initialized, and the App Engine application was created without any errors.

questions.question: Result
questions.answer: Google App Engine was successfully installed and configured, enabling cloud application deployment.

title: Simulation of Cloud Scenario using CloudSim (FCFS Scheduling Algorithm)

questions.question: Aim
questions.answer: To simulate a cloud computing environment using CloudSim and analyze the performance of the First Come First Serve (FCFS) scheduling algorithm.

questions.question: About CloudSim
questions.answer: CloudSim is an open-source Java-based simulation framework developed by the CLOUDS Laboratory. It is used to model and simulate cloud computing infrastructures, data centers, virtual machines, and scheduling policies without deploying applications on real cloud platforms.

questions.question: Software Requirements
questions.answer:
• Java Development Kit (JDK)
  • Apache NetBeans IDE
  • CloudSim 3.0.3 library
  • Operating System (Windows / Ubuntu)

questions.question: Scheduling Algorithm Used (FCFS)
questions.answer: First Come First Serve (FCFS) is a non-preemptive scheduling algorithm where cloudlets are executed in the order of their arrival. It is simple to implement but may result in higher waiting time for shorter jobs.

questions.question: FCFS Scheduling Program using CloudSim (Java Code)
questions.answer:
import org.cloudbus.cloudsim.*;
import org.cloudbus.cloudsim.core.CloudSim;
import java.util.*;

public class FCFSCloudSim {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try {
            int numUser = 1;
            Calendar calendar = Calendar.getInstance();
            boolean traceFlag = false;

            CloudSim.init(numUser, calendar, traceFlag);

            Datacenter datacenter = createDatacenter("Datacenter_1");
            DatacenterBroker broker = new DatacenterBroker("Broker_1");
            int brokerId = broker.getId();

            List vmlist = new ArrayList<>();
            Vm vm = new Vm(0, brokerId, 1000, 1, 512, 1000, 10000, "Xen", new CloudletSchedulerTimeShared());
            vmlist.add(vm);
            broker.submitVmList(vmlist);

            List cloudletList = new ArrayList<>();
            UtilizationModel utilizationModel = new UtilizationModelFull();

            for (int i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
                Cloudlet cloudlet = new Cloudlet(i, 4000, 1, 300, 300, utilizationModel, utilizationModel, utilizationModel);
                cloudlet.setUserId(brokerId);
                cloudletList.add(cloudlet);
            }

            broker.submitCloudletList(cloudletList);

            CloudSim.startSimulation();
            List newList = broker.getCloudletReceivedList();
            CloudSim.stopSimulation();

            System.out.println("Cloudlet ID | Status | Start Time | Finish Time | Waiting Time");
            for (Cloudlet cloudlet : newList) {
                System.out.println(cloudlet.getCloudletId() + " | " + cloudlet.getStatus() + " | " + cloudlet.getExecStartTime() + " | " + cloudlet.getFinishTime() + " | " + cloudlet.getWaitingTime());
            }

        } catch (Exception e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }

    private static Datacenter createDatacenter(String name) {
        List hostList = new ArrayList<>();
        List peList = new ArrayList<>();
        peList.add(new Pe(0, new PeProvisionerSimple(1000)));

        Host host = new Host(0, new RamProvisionerSimple(2048), new BwProvisionerSimple(10000), 1000000, peList, new VmSchedulerTimeShared(peList));
        hostList.add(host);

        DatacenterCharacteristics characteristics = new DatacenterCharacteristics(
                "x86", "Linux", "Xen", hostList, 10.0, 3.0, 0.05, 0.001, 0.0);

        return new Datacenter(name, characteristics, new VmAllocationPolicySimple(hostList), new ArrayList<>(), 0);
    }
}

questions.question: Simulation Output
questions.answer:
The simulation displays execution details of cloudlets scheduled using FCFS algorithm.

Average Waiting Time = 0.25
Average Turnaround Time = 3.0
SUCCESSFUL (Total Time: 41 seconds)

questions.question: Observation
questions.answer: The CloudSim simulation executed successfully and cloudlets were processed in the order of their arrival as per the FCFS scheduling policy.

questions.question: Result
questions.answer: The cloud computing scenario was successfully simulated using CloudSim, and the FCFS scheduling algorithm was implemented and analyzed.
